comment.author: 8498561@N08
comment._content:
Presumably William served with Lt A G Sharp, the next photograph in the sequence?

Cadet Willam Hamo Vernon joined the 4th (City of London) Battalion, The London Regiment (Royal Fusiliers) on 16th January , 1915, from the Cambridge University Contingent, Senior Division, Officers Training Corps, gazetted as a Second Lieutenant. (London Gazette). He was gazetted as Lieutenant , with precedence as from 1st June 1916, on 24th March 1917.

1/4th (City of London) Battalion (Royal Fusiliers) had joined 168th Brigade of 56th (London) Division on 9th February 1916. 

Soldiers Died in the Great War indicates that 4th Battalion lost 54 other ranks and 5 officers in action on the day that William was declared missing. Two of the officers are interred at A.I.F Burial Ground, Flers. At this period 56th Div were involved in an action during the Battle of the Somme that became referred to as the Battle of le Transloy Ridges(7th-20th Oct 1916 ). 

The Battle of Le Transloy was initially planned to commence on 5th October but was postponed due to poor weather. A barrage was opened at 1515hrs on 6th. On the extreme right of the attack, 56th Div were tasked with capturing the German trenches to the east of the village of Lesboeufs before moving to their second objective, establishing a line on the forward slopes of the Transloy Ridges. William and the men of 4th Battalion began the advance at 1345hrs on the 7th and the Brigade's advance faltered after some localised successes. ('When the Barrage Lifts').

William's parents donated a church organ to St Mary's, East Barnet, in his memory. It was dedicated in 1920. His parent's address was given as Bohon Lodge. Moving to think that the Remembrance Service hymns are still played on this tribute from parents to their son.

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content: The 1901 census records the family living at 25 Bidstone Road, Prenton, Birkenhead. Father - William Allen [b.1861 Checkley, Staffs.], Mother – Elizabeth [b. 1866 Caverswall, Staffs.], brothers Herbert William b.1891 Caverswall Staffs], Reginald Thornycroft [b.1893 Caverswell, Staffs.], Wilfred [b.1896 Sefton] and sisters Daisy H [b. 1894, Sefton], Helen DW [b.1900, Sefton] along with six domestic servants. His father’s occupation is given as “Flour Miller”. He was head of the company William Vernon & Sons , millers of West Float, Birkenhead. The company were also responsible for the design and construction of Millennium Mills in the Royal Victoria Dock, London, “Millennium Mills was designed and built by millers William Vernon & Sons of West Float, Birkenhead in 1905 with construction overseen by W. A. Vernon, the principal's son. The mills were extensive, featuring two plants, equipped by Henry Simon Ltd, that had a capacity of 100 sacks per hour. W. A. Vernon described the mills in a single word as "palatial". Vernon and Sons named the mill after their most successful product, a flour variety which they called "Millennium Flour" after winning the "The Miller Challenge Cup" at the 1899 International Bakers Exhibition. The flour had been selected from "the best wheats of the world" and was put through a carefully designed industrial process. The victory gained Vernon and Sons "world-wide fame" and dominance in the English flour market. Millennium Flour was aimed at the rising twentieth-century masses, proving particularly popular in the mining districts, where it was known to make "beautiful white bread sandwiches." The erection of Millennium Mills at the Royal Victoria Dock meant that this new flour could be brought to the Southern England market”. All of these mills were partially destroyed in 1917 by the Silvertown explosion at Brunner Mond's munitions factory on the North Woolwich Road. Vernon & Sons was taken over by Spillers ltd in 1920 and Millennium Mills was rebuilt as a 10-storey concrete art deco building in 1933.
